msItem.title: Óðalsbrigði
msItem.incipit: Nv skipta menn Brædur Tueir edur fleire ödulum syn J mille
msItem.explicit: Alltt þad er .I. þeirra kaup kom
msItem.filiation: This manuscript is a copy of AM 69 4to and was copied in AM 59 b 4to (Storm: Norges gamle LoveIV546) .

supportDesc.support: Paper with watermark. There are two different watermarks. The watermark on the original leaves is visible in the second quire in the middle of the bifolios 4+7 and 5+6. This watermark is a fool's cap and is similar to the one used by Gerrit Pietersz van der Ley in 1674-1675. A countermark for this watermark could not be identified due to repair of the leaves. The second watermark appears in the center of the front flyleaves (1 bifolium). It is the coat of arms of Amsterdam.

foliation.p: There is later foliation in grey ink in the upper right-hand corner of every leaf.

collation.p:
There are two quires:
I: fols. 1-3 (1, 2, 3): The first three leaves are singletons, of which the second and third have been joined during later repair.
II: fols. 4-7 (4+7, 5+6)
collation.catchwords: There is a catchword on every page.

condition.p: The leaves have suffered damage around the edges and have been reapired by means of white Japanese paper.

layout.p: The manuscript is written in one column with 24 to 26 lines per page and 10 to 15 words a line
The dimensions of the written area are ca. 150 120 .

handNote.p: The manuscript is written in one hand of an unidentified scribe using chancery script.

decoDesc.decoNote: There are decorated black initials of varying size (penwork). The biggest (fol. 1r) is six lines tall, the smallest only one (e.g. fol. 5v). Most initials are decorated with squiggles and floral elements. There are no figures.
Each chapter ends with a small, in-line cross or tilde-like signs. There are three small, in-line tilde-like signs at the end of the text before the final rubric on 7r.

additions.p: Fol. 1r has the number (30) scribbled in the right-hand margin near line 18 (in brown ink).
Fol. 3v shows the following note in light brown ink in the outer margin: R.B.C.K.(?) Domserfed verjanda og sækjanda
Fol. 5r shows the following note in dark brown in in the outer margin: NB Verd fyrer brigdada jord,

binding.p: The binding is made of light handmade paper on cardboard. On the front cover is written No 59 A. in black ink. Originally, the letter was B., but was crossed out using grey ink and replaced with A.. Below, Odals Bälkr is written in black ink. Inside the front cover, Kålund has written 7 bl (+ i AMsk seddel) and the date, 24 April 1888 written 24/7 88. In addition to that, the shelfmark ist repeated twice in later hands inside the front cover.
Stored in one box with AM 59 b 4to. The same box also holds strings and narrow paper strips, which were removed from the binding during restauration.

accMat.p: There is a bifolium ( 185 142 ) from Árni Magnússon's time in front of the manuscript (now counted as front flyleaves). On the recto-side of the second fly leaf, Árni Magnússon has written: Ur bök sem fyrrum hefr ätt Magnus Jons son lỏgmadur, enn eg feck fra Gudrunu Þorgilsdöttur.

origin.p: The manuscript was probably written in Iceland and is a copy of AM 69 4to (Storm: Norges gamle LoveIV546). Kålund (KatalogI378) dates it to the end of the 17th century.

provenance.p: It is unclear if the bifolium from Árni Magnússon's time belongs to this copy or rather belonging to AM 59 b 4to, and thus to which manuscript the provenance information applies (see also Storm: Norges gamle LoveIV 546 ). Similar information, that Árni Magnússon bought the larger manuscript from Guðrún Þorgilsdóttir in 1710 is given in a slip in AM 213 a 4to.

source.p: Catalogued 16 August 2017 by JR and LP.
